author: {'steamid': '76561198092126420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1511227876}
review:
Harvest Moon: Light of Hope (HMLH) overall has an authentic feel to the series as well as having a compelling story, which is a rare mixture for today's rpg games. 

HMLH follows the generic storyline from past games; A lost goddess, a farmer saviour, and a whole lot of farming simulation in order to save a goddess. Though this is very similar to past games, it will do a treat for a newer generation of gamers and new platforms. 

Though the story is intersting to follow, the graphics aren't something to be consider 'next gen'. The sprites (Crops, Rocks, Trees, Buildings and Furniture) all look as if they have been enlarged from a smaller image, creating a dissatisfy pixelated look. The player looks like something straight from the original WII series, which struggles to fit in with the other art styles. The players running animation not only does not work the way it's intended, the player almost seems to be floating over the ground, rather than walking. 

While walking you will encounter numerous obsticles. These obsticales are not something that you would expect, as they aren't intended to be in the game. The mesh around each object does not fit the size of the sprite, causing your player to constantly get stuck on weeds and rocks while trying to farm. 

Farming is what made the Harvest Moon series different to other RPG's and the mechanics always seemed to be spot on! But not in this game, this game was a massive let down. The fact that tools are automatically selected and not able to be manually selected makes farming a hassle. Honestly trying to chop down a tree has never been so hard! You somehow miss the tree, and end up hoeing the ground!

Lastly the port was a massive let down for PC, the start screen says touch, the control icons are from XBOX and the totourial is on keyboard and mouse! I've never been so confused with controls in my life! ARMA 2 has easier controls to understand! Overall I recomend playing this game on a controller, it is much easier control.

To conclude I do not recomend this game for the retail price of $30 thus far. The game should have been delayed from release, graphics made to at least be at a default of 1080p, all animation at 30-60fps and lastly the port fixed to know what device you are playing on.

You can watch my first time playing here for any references: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_J6IfPe4dnc

author: {'steamid': '76561197960286640', 'num_games_owned': 3291, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1510939576}
review:
So far an enjoyable experience.

Seeing as it's a Harvest Moon Game which Stardew Valley was inspired by, it's of no surprise that reviews will compare the two.

Standalone this game holds it's own, It features everything a classic Harvest Moon should.
The mouse controls work well and keyboard is only just minor adjustment behind.
Unfortunately the experience is a little spoilt by clashing character models and world aesthetics.

[h1]Mouse controls work beautifully.[/h1]

In menus the mouse is confirm (left mouse) and back (right mouse)

I click a tile on the ground and it does the action it needs. chop trees, break rocks, till the soil. Can all be done with a simple click for each action, the character will move to the tile and do the action.

If you click on a tile ready to plant it will bring up a simple selection to pick the seed, and you can click the arrows to go previous and next seeds.

[h1]Keyboard, unfortunately has minor problems[/h1]

You can move the character with W,A,S and D and this works well.
Unfortunately for some reason they chose to use I think F1 and F2 as default for previous pane and next pane.
This is easily remedied by changing it to Q and E. This makes farm life very smooth.

[h1]Graphics are aesthetically disjointed[/h1]

I found the aesthetics of the characters and world to be very different, 

I found myself enjoying them both separately but the mix of the two clashes for me.
I was able to lose focus of the character while farming and focus on the characters while talking the the NPC's

I feel a more shortened character models would have proven to suit the world more.

[h1]Odd instructions, Steam version before console, inexperienced PC developer?[/h1]

The player is given the instruction to "Tap Screen", a PC player might at first glance jump to conclusions and write this game off.

Although, Getting into the game, the player is also greeted with controller prompts.

While also, the mouse controls work perfectly but are not shown.

On top of this the developer has chosen to release this on the PC before the consoles.

With all this in mind, I can't help but feel the developer is using the ability to rapidly patch within the steam platform as a means to get the game ready for other platforms where patching is somewhat more difficult

I have to hope they are dipping their toes in to PC development and are just inexperienced to the needs of a PC user, I hope they will polish what they have. only time will tell.

[h1]Stardew Valley or This[/h1]

If you had to pick one of the other for a PC user, I'd have to pick Stardew Valley, simply because of being able to modify it to add anything you liked from Harvest Moon: Light of Hope.

but from what I have played of this so far, I would recommend this game for any fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077808520', 'num_games_owned': 2368, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1510769158}
review:
No problems with frame rate and graphically it was ok so far. 

The minute you start the game you have "Tap Screen"
Now if your trying to hide your just mobile porting 
something over I don't know maybe at least try? 

From the very onset I can tell it was just ported
over with no regard on coming to pc. 
All the walking, menu, UI all are a direct port and it shows. 
Currently my Xbox one Wireless controller doesn't work at all on this as well. 

I've played the harvest moon games throughout the years and "this" does
not encompass the spirit of Harvest Moon at best it has been possessed 
by Electronic Arts. 
Always regarded Natsume as a company but this is a travesty to the Harvest Moon
name.

Going with majority to give this a big fat [b]NO[/b]. Priced at 10$ or less, fine. At $30 state of the port is horrible. Tap here to continue screens. Zero game or resolution options to speak of which means both giant jaggies and sprite edges flickering. No control remapping & achievements all popped when I quit. Need I go on? Barely worthwhile from a nostalgic point of view as graphically speaking it's kind of like playing certain older FF remakes. Not good!

author: {'steamid': '76561198285971047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1587518356}
review:
I went into playing this with an open mind. As seen from the preview, the art isn't Pixar quality. But, the npcs all have very cute emotional animations that makes playing more immersive. At first, I was taken aback by the art but after two hours it is growing on me. I don't mind it. It could have been better, I agree. But it's not horrible. 

The controls confused me a little bit at first, but it's nice how they made it so you don't have to switch around in your controls to select the needed tool. It automatically selects the necessary tool you need whether it is plowing, chopping, planting, or watering. You just click. In the long run, this takes out the jarring portion of any farming game where you need to constantly choose the correct tool. (Sometimes selecting the wrong one and wasting energy). I feel like the developers put a lot of thought and effort into this portion of the game.

I only played 2 hours into the game, so I can't say much for story yet. But I feel like they could have put a little bit more effort into the intro. It's pretty much a copy paste of past harvest moons.... But hey, the title of this game is 'harvest moon.' Maybe this is their signature thing for their game lol. 

The two hours flew past really fast for me. I really love farming games so I bought it even though the preview threw me off. If you like farming games, try it~

author: {'steamid': '76561198065050081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 894, 'last_played': 1653850925}
review:
I'm now 20 hours into this game, and on the last stretch of the main story.

Just like my initial impression, I am generally pleased by this game and love how it plays on my Windows tablet. I do have my gripes with the game, which I'll discuss in this review, but overall I really like it and still recommend it.

This game is extremely versatile when it comes to how and where you can play it. It has three main input methods that work interchangeably and seamlessly: Keyboard, gamepad and mouse/touch. You can mix and match, but they work best on their own. I've noticed some people playing the game on streams and youtube trying to play this like it's Stardew Valley, and while it's possible, it's definitely not optimal. This versatility means I can confortably play this on my tablet, without any extra peripherals attached, which is already the number one thing I wanted from this game.

The farming works great in this game, it's possibly the best farming gameplay in the series, and it has some hidden depth to it that may throw some people off. Crops have their favorite seasons where they grow well and happy, but you can plant any crop or flower in any season, they'll just need some extra help (fertilizer) to keep them alive. There's four different types of soil types, and many fertilizers you can use. This combination of season, soil and fertilizer can make certain crops change and mutate into different, usually more valuable variations.

There's a ton of different muations to discover, and registering them all in your encyclopedia is one of the many optional goals you can achieve, and probably the most time consuming.

Compared to Natsume's previous entries in the series, this one takes the best from their past experiments, and combines it with a more traditional top down gameplay style that, while a bit underwhelming for people used to PC gaming, works great for people like me with weaker hardware.

Graphically, I don't mind it, it looks just like their other games, which looked fine to me to begin with. But I do understand other's reactions, as I said, it still looks the same as their previous three games, games released on weaker hardware and systems with tiny screens. I think it's certainly time for Natsume to try some new graphics.

Of course, the game is not perfect, and there's some quirks that should be addressed.

For starters, there's some noticeable graphical issues that happen with some characters like Sam, Doc, and Elise, where parts of their models clip through each other as they interact or move around. Some background elements also have noticeable differences in style and quality, for example, the palm trees are in a really nice hand-drawn artstyle, while the other two types of trees are renders of a 3D model. The same goes for multiple other things, like the houses, where it's clear they have different origins and styles.

Some lines of dialog and quests are awkward, and/or confusing. This is specially noticeable when playing through several parts of the storyline, for example, there's a bit where for no reason you must first build the house of an unrelated NPC before the game will allow you to find the item you need, and this is AFTER the game explicitly told you how find the mcguffin in question. 

Little confusions like that are present through the entire story, and will likely stump several players. Curiously enough, while the game keeps track of minor sidequests you get in the mail, the main story quests are not recorded at all.

Another gripe I have with the game is that mining for gems is so profitable, risk free, and easy that it basically trivializes farming as a source of income. Because, why bother using the multiple huge fields you have available for agriculture, when mining for a day will give you more money that you'll get for a week of farm work? And it's not like mining is optional, because you'll need lots of resources from that mine, and the gems will be just byproduct.

Anyway, all things considered, I really like this game, I think more people should give it a chance (waiting for a sale is always good, though), and I hope it will continue to be polished and grow as time goes on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029088348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1510693225}
review:
The Bad Things:
1. It looks like it's a poorly optimized mobile port ("tap screen", really?)
2. My PC can handle Witcher 3 on ultra settings. It seems it can't handle this game :D (poor FPS)
3. The graphics - it looks like someone planted 3D models on backgrounds taken from RPG Maker stock. The devs wrote they wanted a nostalgic feeling, but I think it could look much better in pixel art (like Stardew Valley or old Gameboy Harvest Moons).
4. You can't skip cutscenes.
5. Character models are bad (the style is a matter of taste, but they're poorly made - for example the traveling salesman's collar is sinking into his thorax as he breathes). Also, you can't customize your character. 
6. Refund, please! (edit: got the refund, thanks!) For me, it's not worth the current price. But I'll probably grab it when it's cheaper/on sale. 

Neutral:
1. You keep a "lvl 1 house" in your BAG :D
2. XBOX controller is working fine for me. 

The Good Things: 
1. You don't have to change tools - an automatic action is chosen (when you press a button near unwatered crop - it's watered, when you press a button near a weed - it's pulled out, when you press a button near a flower - it's pulled out and put into your inventory).
2. Rebuilding of a village sounds fun.
3. The gameplay seems OK.

I feel a bit cheated for this price, if you're a Harvest Moon fan and you feel nostalgic, better wipe the dust off your Gameboy/3DS/whatever and play the old games. Or try Stardew Valley. Or try Rune Factory (it's AWESOME). And wait for the sale because I'm not saying it's a totally bad game, just that IMHO it's not worth that much - that's why I don't recommend getting it now.
